summary: Henry P. Lopez was a CIA asset who worked for the Mexico City Station from 1961 to 1966. He was involved in operational activities and discussions regarding intelligence gathering in Spain. Documents detail his activities, expenses, cover arrangements, and termination settlements with the CIA, including the use of proprietary companies and potential operational deployments. He was also involved in discussions about influencing Fidel Castro and exploiting weaknesses within his regime in 1960. Later, he worked as a legal consultant for WUSALINE in New York City. The House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA) requested assistance from the CIA to interview him in Mexico in 1978.
significance: Henry P. Lopez's significance in the JFK assassination context stems from the HSCA's interest in interviewing him in Mexico, suggesting he may have had information relevant to their investigation. His prior involvement with the CIA, particularly his work in Mexico City and his connections to individuals and operations related to Cuba, could have been of interest to the HSCA.
